titleStmt.title: Molecular assessment of wild populations in the marine realm: Importance of taxonomic, seasonal and habitat patterns in environmental monitoring

analytic.title: Molecular assessment of wild populations in the marine realm: Importance of taxonomic, seasonal and habitat patterns in environmental monitoring

keywords.term: Cellular stress response AOX, antioxidant enzymes

abstract.p: Scientists are currently faced with the challenge of assessing the effects of anthropogenic stressors on aquatic ecosystems. Cellular stress response (CSR) biomarkers are ubiquitous and phylogenetically conserved among metazoans and have been successfully applied in environmental monitoring but they can also vary according to natural biotic and abiotic factors. The reported variability may thus limit the wide application of biomarkers in monitoring, imposing the need to identify variability levels in the field. Our aim was to carry out a comprehensive in situ assessment of the CSR (heat shock protein 70 kDa, ubiquitin, antioxidant enzymes) and oxidative damage (lipid peroxidation) in wild populations across marine taxa by collecting fish, crustaceans, mollusks and cnidarians during two different seasons (spring and summer) and two habitat types (coast and estuary). CSR end-point patterns were different between taxa with mollusks having higher biomarker levels, followed

div.head: H I G H L I G H T S
div.p: • Stress biomarkers were assessed in marine taxa to improve environmental monitoring. • Stress biomarker levels ranking:

mollusks N cnidarians N fish and crustaceans • Sessile/sedentary species had higher biomarker levels. • Seasonal differences were especially evident in fish and cnidarians. • Habitat type influences stress biomarker patterns in marine taxa.

div.head: G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
div.p: a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Scientists are currently faced with the challenge of assessing the effects of anthropogenic stressors on aquatic communities. Several effective and reliable molecular tools (e.g. specific molecular markers, omics technology) have been established, helping to improve environmental monitoring approaches and environmental risk assessment (Ge et al., 2013;Quintero and Zafra, 2016). These tools can be combined with histo-pathological, morphological and behavioral assessments to characterize the eco-toxicity of pollutants and sub-lethal metabolic effects of general stressors in aquatic organisms. Currently, several molecular markers have been successfully applied in environmental monitoring including biotransformation enzymes, cellular stress response (CSR) proteins, metal-binding cysteine rich proteins, endocrine system proteins, programed cell death markers, bile metabolites and DNA integrity markers (Adams et al., 2001;Peixoto et al., 2013;Quintero and Zafra, 2016). Within CSR proteins, the interplay between heat shock proteins (hsp), ubiquitin and antioxidant enzymes (AOX) is especially relevant for cell functioning. Hsp and ubiquitin are two major components of the protein quality control system, which is a network of molecular chaperones and protein degradation factors that maintains the integrity of the protein pool (Chen et al., 2011). Hsp are molecular chaperones that regulate protein folding/re-folding, protein trafficking, cytoskeletal arrangements, and modulate the immune system providing tolerance to the deleterious effects of an array of stress factors (temperature, salinity, pollution, infection and others) (Iwama et al., 1999;Sung, 2013). Moreover, Hsp can direct the degradation of irreversibly denatured proteins by sending them to the ubiquitin-proteasome system in which ubiquitin tags the proteins (by polyubiquitination) for destruction in the 26S proteasome, preventing cytotoxic aggregations and controlling protein levels and trafficking (Chen et al., 2011). The activation of antioxidant enzymes is also a crucial part of the cellular stress response (Troschinski et al., 2014). The oxidative burden of cells is known to increase under stressful conditions (e.g. warming, pollutants) due to an increased production of Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS), which can result in oxidative stress and consequent damage to cellular components (e.g. lipid peroxidation, protein carbonylation, DNA deletions and mutations) (Lackner, 1998;Lesser, 2006). ROS are continuously produced by cells due to mitochondrial respiration and act as signaling molecules under normal conditions (D'Autréaux and Toledano, 2007). However, changes in the steady-state concentration of ROS elicit the activation of antioxidant enzymes, which quench these highly unstable free radicals by catalyzing the reactions that transform them into non-toxic products (Martínez-Álvarez et al., 2005). Superoxide dismutase integrates the first line of defense by catalyzing the dismutation of the superoxide radical into oxygen and hydrogen peroxide. Following, both catalase and glutathione peroxidase detoxify hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen (Das and Roychoudhury, 2014). Additionally, glutathione related enzymes (peroxidase and S-transferase) detoxify lipid peroxides by transforming them into alcohols (Sharma et al., 2004).

The genes and pathways involved in the cellular stress response (CSR) are ubiquitous and phylogenetically conserved among metazoans (Kultz, 2003) but the composition, rate of up-regulation and posttranslational regulation of each protein class can vary (Richter et al., 2010;Zhang et al., 2015). Moreover, extrinsic (stress levels, previous exposures, season, geographic location, habitat) and intrinsic factors (tissue, sex, age-class, nutritional status) are known to influence CSR proteins (Dietz and Somero, 1993;Feidantsis et al., 2013;Madeira et al., 2014aMadeira et al., , 2012Mizrahi et al., 2016;Vinagre et al., 2012). For example, seasonal variation has been widely reported in biomarker studies, depending on sex, organ and location (Borges et al., 2018;Chainy et al., 2016;Luna-Acosta et al., 2010;Pavlović et al., 2013). No general trend can be asserted as responses are species-specific but summer and/or winter seem to be the most stressful seasons, with significant changes in biomarker levels (Chainy et al., 2016;Manduzio et al., 2004). Oxidative stress biomarkers have been shown to vary with season in multiple species including the Pacific oyster, the mussels Perna viridis (Verlecar et al., 2008) and Mytilus edulis and galloprovincialis (Balbi et al., 2017;Nahrgang et al., 2013), Icelandic scallop, cod (Nahrgang et al., 2013), the crabs Aegla singularis (Borges et al., 2018) and Scylla serrata (Paital and Chainy, 2013), octocorals (Madeira et al., 2015), shrimps (Madeira et al., 2016) and krill (Tremblay et al., 2010), among others.

The reported variability may thus limit the wide application of such biomarkers in environmental monitoring, imposing the need to identify baseline variability levels in the field and standardize collection times and age-classes in sampling plans (Cuevas et al., 2015;Dalzochio and Gehlen, 2016).

Based on this framework, our aim was to carry out a comprehensive and integrative assessment of the CSR and oxidative damage in wild populations across marine taxa and identify (i) taxonomic, (ii) seasonal and (iii) habitat differentiation patterns as baseline data to improve environmental monitoring and conservation efforts. We hypothesize (i) that sessile organisms possess higher basal levels of CSR proteins than mobile organisms as they cannot escape unfavorable conditions, (ii) season is a major confounding factor as it influences CSR proteins and lipid peroxidation levels across marine taxa; (iii) there is a differentiation in CSR profiles between populations of the same species that live in different habitat types (estuary vs coast); (iv) CSR proteins have high intraspecific variability.

div.head: Ethical statement
div.p: All procedures followed European laws on animal welfare (Directive 2010/63/EU) and were approved by Direcção Geral de Alimentação e Veterinária.

div.head: Study areas and collection of species
div.p: The organisms' collection was performed -on 29th and 30th of April (spring) and 27th and 28th of June (summer) 2013, in a rocky intertidal coastal shore (Cabo Raso, Cascais, latitude 38°42′N, longitude 9°29′W) and sandy intertidal estuarine shore (Tróia, Setúbal, latitude 38°29′N, longitude 8°53′W) with a few rocky areas ( Fig. 1). Both of these sampling sites are located within natural parks and are considered pristine. These seasons were chosen because the sampling periods recommended for biomonitoring studies are usually between spring and autumn, excluding winter for logistic reasons (Sanchez et al., 2008). The organisms were collected from 4 to 5 tide pools (mean ± sd depth of 0.26 ± 0.10 m) located in middle to high shore (~100 m sampled) during low tide peaks that occurred during the hottest hours of the day (around 14:00 h). The organisms collected (Table 1 for details) in the coast (Cabo Raso) were fishes (Lipophrys trigloides, Valenciennes 1836; Lepadogaster lepadogaster, Bonnaterre 1788), shrimps (Palaemon elegans, Rathke 1837), gastropods (Gibbula umbilicalis, da Costa 1778; Phorcus lineatus, da Costa 1778; Patella depressa, Pennant 1777; Aplysia punctata, Cuvier 1803), sea anemones (Actinia equina, Linnaeus 1758; Anemonia sulcata, Pennant 1777), bivalves (Mytilus galloprovincialis, Linnaeus 1758), and polyplacophores (Lepidochitona cinerea, Linnaeus 1767). In the estuary (Tróia), the species collected were crabs (Carcinus maenas, Linnaeus 1758), hermit crabs (Pagurus bernhardus, Linnaeus 1758), gastropods (Phorcus lineatus), sea anemones (Actinia equina), bivalves (Mytilus galloprovincialis) and polyplacophores (Chaetopleura angulata, Spengler 1797). All of these are key species in the intertidal and subtidal ecosystems, playing important roles as grazers, predators or prey of high trophic levels. Additionally, some of these species are used as bioindicators in estuarine and coastal systems. All the species were collected by hand or using hand nets and were immediately frozen, in situ, in dry ice.

div.head: Field data acquisition
div.p: Physical and chemical parameters (air temperature, water temperature, salinity and water pH) were measured at least 3 times in each intertidal pool where organisms were collected (using a glass thermometer Wolf X-ray USA, a hand-held refractometer Atago Japan and a digital pH probe model HI9025 Hanna Instruments USA, respectively). For long-term data and tidal-cycle variations see supplementary files (Figs. S1 and S2). Photoperiod was assessed from http://www.goldenhour.com.

div.head: Extraction of proteins from tissues
div.p: Depending on the type of organism (considering its size and/or anatomy) either muscle or whole body were homogenized for protein analysis (see Table 1). Samples (approximately 50-200 mg depending on the species and size) were homogenized in 1 mL phosphate buffered saline (0.14 M NaCl, 0.003 M KCl, 0.01 M Na 2 HPO 4 , 0.002 M KH 2 PO 4 , pH 7.4) using an Ultra-Turrax® T10 basic homogenizer (Ika, Germany), on ice cold conditions. The crude homogenates were then centrifuged at 4°C Fig. 1. Collection sites (i) rocky coastal shore (Cabo Raso, Cascais, latitude 38°42′N, longitude 9°29′W) and (ii) sandy estuarine shore with a few rocky areas (Tróia, Setúbal, latitude 38°29′ N, longitude 8°53′W). Bathymetric lines for 30 and 100 m depth are marked in the figure. Species collected in Cabo Raso (coast) were fishes (Lipophrys trigloides; Lepadogaster lepadogaster), shrimps (Palaemon elegans), gastropods (Gibbula umbilicalis; Phorcus lineatus; Patella depressa; Aplysia punctata), sea anemones (Actinia equina; Anemonia sulcata), bivalves (Mytilus galloprovincialis), and polyplacophores (Lepidochitona cinerea). In Tróia (estuary), the species collected were crabs (Carcinus maenas), hermit crabs (Pagurus bernhardus), gastropods (Phorcus lineatus), sea anemones (Actinia equina), bivalves (Mytilus galloprovincialis) and polyplacophores (Chaetopleura angulata). The photographs were taken by team members D. Madeira, R. Cereja, C. Madeira, and M.S. Diniz. for 15 min at 10,000 ×g. The supernatants were frozen immediately (−80°C) until further analyses.

div.head: Total protein
div.p: Total protein content was determined through the Bradford method (Bradford, 1976) for data normalization and followed the protocol described by Madeira et al. (2014b).

div.head: CSR proteins
div.p: Heat Shock Protein 70 kDa (Hsc70/Hsp70) was quantified using an indirect Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) (Njemini et al., 2005) while total ubiquitin (Ub) was quantified through a direct ELISA, both with 96-well microplates. Both quantifications followed the protocols described by Madeira et al. (2014b). Antibody reactivity for both Hsp70 and -ubiquitin was previously tested via western blot for all species. The enzymatic assay of catalase (CAT) (EC 1.11.1.6) was adapted from Johansson and Borg (1988) and performed as described in Vinagre et al. (2014) in 96-well microplates. Catalase activity was calculated considering that one unit of catalase is defined as the amount that will cause the formation of 1.0 nmol of formaldehyde per minute at 25°C. The enzymatic assay of glutathione S-transferase (GST) activity (EC 2.5.1.18), using the substrate CDNB (1-Chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene), was adapted from Habig et al. (1974) and performed as described by Vinagre et al. (2014) in 96-well microplates and using a molar extinction coefficient for CDNB of 0.0053εmM (adapted for microplates). The enzymatic assay of superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity (EC Table 2 Physical and chemical parameters (mean ± sd of photoperiod, air temperature, water temperature, salinity and water pH) measured during the organisms' collection from the infralittoral to the supralittoral area (n = 5 pools in each area). Each parameter was measured at least 3 times during the collection time (low tides).

div.head: Site
div.p: Month 2. Principal components analysis (PCA) carried out to assess differences in biomarker patterns between taxonomic groups in the field. (a) Projection of the variables on the factor plane, (b) Projection of the cases on the factor plane and 95% confidence intervals for each group, (c) Heatmap representation of the clustered data in which cells denote the glog (generalized logarithm transformation) values of biomarker normalized concentration/activity. The colour scale ranges from orange (higher than mean biomarker concentration/activity) to blue (lower than mean biomarker concentration/activity). The MANOVA confirmed significant differences between taxa (Wilks = 0.027, F = 10.1, effect df = 18, error df = 71.2, p = 0.000) and Tukey's post-hoc tests were significant for SOD, Hsp70 and LPO. Specimens were collected in a rocky coastal shore (Cabo Raso -CR, Cascais, latitude 38°42′N, longitude 9°29′W) and a sandy estuarine shore (Tróia -T, Setúbal, latitude 38°29′N, longitude 8°53′W) in spring (April) and summer (June). Analyses were carried out using average data from all species, including both locations and seasons. Heat shock protein Hsp70, total ubiquitin Ub, glutathione-S-transferase GST, catalase CAT, superoxide dismutase SOD, lipid peroxidation LPO. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 3. Comparison of biomarker patterns between sedentary/sessile and mobile species. Principal components analysis carried out using spring data (log transformed and pareto-scaled) for all species, collected in Portugal in a rocky coastal shore (Cabo Raso, Cascais, latitude 38°42′N, longitude 9°29′W) and a sandy estuarine shore (Tróia -T, Setúbal, latitude 38°29′N, longitude 8°53′W). (a) Projection of the variables on the factor plane, (b) Projection of the cases on the factor plane and 95% confidence intervals (c, d) Box and whisker plots (median, 25th-75th percentiles and min-max) for cellular stress response (CSR) protein data and oxidative damage (lipid peroxidation) of sedentary/sessile vs mobile species. Sedentary/sessile organisms showed significantly higher basal levels/activity of CSR proteins (t = 2.8, df = 12, p = 0.015) and LPO levels (U = 1, p = 0.004) when compared to mobile organisms (marked with an asterisk). (e) Fold-change analysis showing how biomarker levels vary from mobile to sessile/sedentary species. Fold-change threshold was set at 2. This analysis corroborates the trend identified in the boxplots, showing that Hsp70, Ub, CAT and LPO (highlighted in pink) are over 2-fold larger in sedentary/sessile species when compared to mobile ones. Besides LPO, significant differences between groups were found for Hsp70 (U = 2, p = 0.005). Heat shock protein Hsp70, total ubiquitin Ub, glutathione-S-transferase GST, catalase CAT, superoxide dismutase SOD, lipid peroxidation LPO. Sedentary/sessile species: Gibbula umbilicalis, Phorcus lineatus, Patella depressa, Actinia equina, Anemonia sulcata, Mytillus galloprovincialis, Lepidochitona cinerea, Chaetopleura angulata; mobile species: Lipophrys trigloides, Lepadogaster lepadogaster, Palaemon elegans, Carcinus maenas, Pagurus bernhardus, Aplysia punctata.
1.15.1.1) was adapted from Sun et al. (1988) and performed using nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) and xanthine oxidase (XOD), as described in Vinagre et al. (2014).

div.head: Oxidative damage products
div.p: The lipid peroxides (LPO) assay was adapted from the thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) protocol (Uchiyama and Mihara, 1978) to quantify malondialdehyde bis(dimethylacetal) (MDA) following the procedure described by Vinagre et al. (2014).
For more details on the methods see Supplementary Table S1.

2.5. Statistical analysis 2.5.1. Principal components analysis Data were (i) log-transformed in order to make data distributions less skewed and reduce heterocedasticity, (ii) pareto-scaled (mean centered and divided by the square root of standard deviation of each variable). Such approaches contribute to normalize the data, put them on the same scale and adjust for magnitude differences, representing fold-changes and controlling for the weight of large fold-changes. Any missing values were replaced by the group mean.

Principal components analyses (PCA) were carried out in MetaboAnalyst 4.0 to detect if biomarker levels differed between: (i) taxonomic groups. For this PCA species were grouped according to taxon: fish (chordata), crustacea (arthropoda), mollusca and cnidaria; mean biomarker values were calculated for each species in each season and used for the PCA. (ii) sedentary/sessile and mobile species. In order to test if sessile organisms possess higher basal levels of CSR proteins and lipid peroxidation, species were grouped according to mobility (1) sedentary/sessile species (Gibbula umbilicalis, Phorcus lineatus, Patella depressa, Actinia equina, Anemonia sulcata, Mytillus galloprovincialis, Lepidochitona cinerea, Chaetopleura angulata) and (2) mobile species (Lipophrys trigloides, Lepadogaster lepadogaster, Palaemon elegans, Carcinus maenas, Pagurus bernhardus, Aplysia punctata). Following, spring individual data was used to determine mean basal biomarker levels (Hsp70, -Ub, CAT, GST, SOD and LPO) of each species before applying the PCA. (iii) season within each taxon. Individual data from each species within each taxon was used for these PCAs. (iv) habitat type using conspecifics of M. galloprovincialis, P. lineatus and A. equina collected from different sites (estuary vs coast) during one season (spring).

(v) Organ (muscle and whole body). Tissue was standardized as much as possible but as species size and anatomy was very different there was a need to collect whole body in some species. In order to ensure the comparability of tissues we chose the taxonomic group with the largest number of species (Mollusca) and did a tissue comparison (with spring data) using species as replicates (4 species for whole body measurements and 3 species for muscle measurements). Following the PCA, a fold-change analysis (threshold set at 2) was also carried out on Metaboanalyst 4.0.

div.head: Hierarchical clustering analysis and heatmaps
div.p: Cluster analyses and heatmaps were carried out in MetaboAnalyst 4.0 using log-transformed and pareto-scaled data, similarly to the PCAs. Cluster analyses followed the criteria (i) cluster rows, (ii) similarity metrics: Pearson correlation, (iii) clustering method: complete linkage.

div.head: Statistical tests
div.p: In addition, statistical tests were applied to detect significant differences between biomarkers for all comparisons (i) taxonomic groups, (ii) sedentary/sessile vs mobile species, (iii) season within each taxon, (iv) habitat type and (v) organ comparison within mollusks. Data was tested for the assumptions of normality (Shapiro-Wilk's test) and homoscedasticity (Levene's test) before the analyses.

For the first comparison (i) taxonomic groups, data was log transformed and a MANOVA was carried out with taxon as independent variable and biomarkers as dependent variables (Hsp70, Ub, SOD, CAT, GST, LPO). Tukey's post-hocs were further applied to detect which biomarkers differed significantly between which taxa.

For the second comparison (ii) sessile/sedentary vs mobile species, a ttest and a Mann-Whitney were applied to CSR and LPO (respectively) to compare response and oxidative damage levels between sedentary/sessile and mobile species. To calculate CSR levels, proteins involved in the CSR were log 2 transformed and grouped (Hsp70, Ub, SOD, CAT and GST), and a mean CSR value was calculated for each species. Statistical comparisons were also carried out for each biomarker individually (ttest or Mann-Whitney, depending on whether the data met the assumptions). In addition, a fold-change analysis was also carried out in Metaboanalyst 4.0 (fold-change threshold set to 2) in order to see how each biomarker varied between sessile/sedentary vs mobile species.

To detect significant differences between (iii) season within each taxon, data was log 2 transformed and MANOVAs were applied. Season was set as the categorical predictor and biomarkers as dependent variables (Hsp70, Ub, SOD, CAT, GST, LPO). Tukey's post-hocs were further applied to detect which biomarkers differed significantly between seasons (spring vs summer).

To compare (iv) habitat type, data was log 2 transformed and a twoway MANOVA was applied. Habitat and species were set as the categorical predictors and biomarkers as dependent variables (Hsp70, Ub, SOD, CAT, GST, LPO). Tukey's post-hocs were further applied to detect which biomarkers differed significantly between habitat types (estuary vs coast).

To compare (v) muscle and whole body within Mollusca, data was log 2 transformed and a MANOVA was applied. Organ was set as the categorical predictor and biomarkers as dependent variables (Hsp70, Ub, SOD, CAT, GST, LPO). Tukey's post-hocs were further applied to detect which biomarkers differed significantly between organs.
All aforementioned analyses were carried out using Statistica software (version 10.0, StatSoft Inc., USA) using a significance level of 0.05.

div.head: Field data
div.p: The seasonal variation in air temperature was approximately 14°C in the coast (13.9-27.5°C) and 12°C in the estuary (17.5-29.0°C).

Seasonal variation in water temperature was around 6°C in supralittoral pools and 4°C in the infra-littoral zone (Table 2) for both locations. Both air and water temperatures were higher in the estuary by 2-4°C, reaching a maximum of 29°C during summer (both air and water). Mean water temperature in the supralittoral zone was around 18-20°C during spring for coast and estuary respectively, increasing to 25-26°C during summer. In the infra-littoral zone, water temperature was approximately 14-18°C during spring for coast and estuary respectively, increasing to 18-22°C during summer. Salinity remained fairly stable in both locations ranging between 35 and 38‰ in the coast and 34-36‰ in the estuary depending on season and littoral zone. Additionally, pH ranged between 8.30 and 8.90 in the coast and 8.07-8.49 in the estuary (Table 2).

div.head: Differences between taxa
div.p: The PCA (Fig. 2) showed that biomarker patterns were different between taxa, which was further confirmed by the MANOVA (Wilks = 0.027, F = 10.1, effect df = 18, error df = 71.2, p = 0.000). Significant differences in the post-hoc Turkey's tests were found for SOD, Hsp70 Fig. 4. Seasonal variation in stress biomarkers assessed in different taxonomic groups (a) Fish, (b) Crustacea, (c) Mollusca and (d) Cnidaria. Specimens were collected in a rocky coastal shore (Cabo Raso -CR, Cascais, latitude 38°42′N, longitude 9°29′W) and a sandy estuarine shore (Tróia -T, Setúbal, latitude 38°29′N, longitude 8°53′W) in spring (April) and summer (June). Principal components analysis was carried out to assess seasonal differences in each taxonomic group, left panels: projection of the variables on the factor plane. Middle panels represent the projections of the cases on the factor plane. Right panels: hierarchical clustering analysis of biomarker data and heat maps of the clustered data matrix in which cells represent the glog values of normalized biomarker concentration/activity. The colour scale ranges from blue (lower than mean biomarker concentration/activity) to orange (higher than mean biomarker concentration/activity). Columns represent different seasons while rows represent different biomarkers. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) and LPO. In the PCA, Hsp70 was strongly correlated to PC1 (r = −0.59) and PC2 (r = 0.59) while CAT was correlated to PC2 (r = −0.71) ( Fig. 2a). Clear taxon clusters were observed when the cases were projected on the factor-plane (Fig. 2b). The cumulative explained variance of PC1 and PC2 was 71.2%. In general, mollusks have higher biomarker levels, followed by the cnidarians, while fish and crustaceans show lower biomarker levels (Fig. 2c). Mollusks have the higher amounts of Hsp70 and cnidarians have the greatest CAT activity and LPO concentration. Ubiquitin levels were higher in fish and cnidarians (Fig. 2c).

The PCA comparing sedentary/sessile vs mobile organisms had a cumulative explained variance (for PC1 and PC2) of 75.9%. Variables strongly correlated to PC1 were Hsp70 (r = 0.60) and LPO (r = 0.55) (Fig. 3a). Ub, Hsp70 and CAT were correlated to PC2 (r = −0.48, r = 0.50, r = −0.69, respectively). A differentiation was observed especially along PC1 (Fig. 3b), with sedentary/sessile species having higher biomarker levels (t-test for CSR, t = 2.8, df = 12, p = 0.015; Mann-Whitney test for LPO, U = 1, p = 0.004) ( Fig. 3c, d). When CSR biomarkers were analyzed individually, the trend of higher levels in sedentary/sessile species is maintained, but only Hsp70 had a significant difference (U = 2, p = 0.005) (Fig. 3e). The fold-change analysis showed that Hsp70 had the largest fold-change (FC = 17.5), followed by LPO (FC = 5.6), Ub (FC = 2.5) and CAT (FC = 2.3).

Intraspecific variability in the CSR measured by the coefficient of variation (% CV) (including data from all seasons and sites) was elevated, ranging approximately from 35 (Pagurus bernhardus) to 94% (Aplysia punctata) (Table 3). The mean intra-biomarker variability was 48 to 83% (GST, SOD and Hsp70 showed the lowest variability taking into account all species analyzed) ( Table 3).

div.head: Differences between seasons
div.p: Overall, there was a seasonal differentiation in biomarker patterns across taxonomic groups, especially evident in fish and cnidarians (see Fig. 4a, b, c, d for PCA outputs). Such results were supported by the MANOVAs (fish: Wilks = 0.22, F = 0.55, effect df = 6, error df = 13, p = 0.001, Tukey's post-hocs were significant for GST, CAT, SOD and Hsp70; cnidarians: Wilks = 0.19, F = 36.5, effect df = 6, error df = 52, p = 0.000, Tukey's post-hocs were significant for all biomarkers except Hsp70) (see the right panels of Fig. 4 for the heat map representation of the data). The cumulative explained variance of the PCA was 67.5% and 76.8% for fish and cnidarians, respectively. In the PCA carried out for fish, the PC-variable correlations were relevant between PC1 and CAT (r = 0.69), PC1 and Ub (r = 0.48). GST and Ub were also correlated with PC2 (r = −0.72 and r = 0.48, respectively). The projection of the cases on the factor plane shows that summer specimens mostly differentiate from spring specimens along PC1 and showed elevated biomarker levels when compared to their spring counterparts (Fig. 4a). With regards to cnidarian data, both CAT and Ub were strongly correlated to PC1 (r = −0.52 and r = −0.58, respectively), while SOD, LPO and Ub were strongly correlated to PC2 (r = −0.48, r = 0.58 and r = 0.54, respectively) ( Fig. 4d). The heatmap illustrates that LPO and Ub were higher in spring specimens; and SOD, GST and CAT were higher in summer specimens (Fig. 4d).

According to the PCA, crustaceans showed no clear differentiation between seasons (Fig. 4b). However, the MANOVA was significant (Wilks = 0.48, F = 7.29, effect df = 6, error df = 42, p = 0.000). Tukey's post hocs showed that the only biomarkers with significant differences were SOD and Ub (see also Fig. 4b, right panel), which was not enough to create clear clusters in the PCA.

According to the PCA on mollusks, there is some overlap between spring and summer specimens, but some summer-collected individuals differentiate mostly along PC2. CAT was strongly correlated to PC1 (r = 0.56) while both CAT and LPO were also correlated to PC2 (r = −0.66 and r = 0.71, respectively). The heatmap illustrates that, in general, spring specimens have greater levels of LPO and lower levels of the other biomarkers when compared to their summer counterparts (Fig. 4c). The MANOVA corroborates such results (Wilks = 0.53, F = 23.7, effect df = 6, error df = 162, p = 0.000; Tukey's post hocs were significant for all biomarkers). Fig. 5. Specimens (of the mussel Mytilus galloprovincialis, the sea anemone Actinia equina and the gastropod Phorcus lineatus) were collected in a coastal rocky shore (Cabo Raso, Cascais, latitude 38°42′N, longitude 9°29′W) and an estuarine sandy shore with a few rocky areas (Tróia, Setúbal, latitude 38°29′N, longitude 8°53′W) in spring (April), (a) Principal component analysis -projection of the variables on the factor plane, (b) Projection of the cases on the factor plane and 95% confidence intervals, (c) Hierarchical clustering analysis of biomarker data and heat maps of the clustered data matrix in which cells represent the log values of normalized biomarker concentration/activity. The colour scale ranges from blue (lower than mean biomarker concentration/activity) to orange (higher than mean biomarker concentration/activity). Data was log transformed and pareto-scaled before all analyses. Heat shock protein Hsp70, total ubiquitin -Ub, glutathione-S-transferase GST, catalase CAT, superoxide dismutase SOD, lipid peroxidation LPO. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

div.head: Differences between habitat types (estuary vs coast)
div.p: A differentiation in biomarker patterns between habitat types was evidenced by the PCA for two out of three species analyzed (M. galloprovincialis and A. equina showed clear habitat clusters while P. lineatus did not) (Fig. 5). The explained cumulative variance for PC 1 and 2 was 68.7%. PC-variable correlations were significant between CAT (r = −0.73), Ub (r = −0.59) and PC1. SOD and Hsp70 were correlated to PC2 (r = −0.60 and r = −0.78, respectively) ( Fig. 5a). The mussel M. galloprovincialis mainly differentiated along PC1, with specimens from the coast having lower scores (associated mostly with higher CAT and Ub) when compared to specimens collected in the estuary. The sea anemone A. equina differentiated along PC1 and 2, indicating that specimens collected in the estuary (clustered in the upper right quadrant of the factor plane) are associated with low biomarker levels (Fig. 5b). The specimens of the gastropod P. lineatus collected from different locations showed an overlap; however, coastal specimens showed greater variability along both PC1 and PC2. Overall, specimens collected in the estuary (Tróia) had lower biomarker levels when compared to specimens collected in the coast (Cabo Raso) (Fig. 5c). The twoway MANOVA supports such results (habitat: Wilks = 0.17, F = 33.5, effect df = 6, error df = 42, p = 0.000; species: Wilks = 0.011, F = 59.7, effect df = 12, error df = 84, p = 0.000; habitat*species: Wilks = 0.061, F = 21.3, effect df = 12, error df = 84, p = 0.000; Tukey's post hocs to compare estuary vs coast were significant for all biomarkers).
For the full MANOVA table see Supplementary material Table S2.

div.head: Differences between organs (whole body vs muscle within Mollusca)
div.p: The PCA showed that whole body and muscle clusters overlap, without a clear differentiation pattern (total cumulative explained variance for PC1 and PC2 was 74.2%). Moreover, fold-changes in biomarker levels between muscle and whole body were lower than 2-fold. The MANOVA was borderline significant (Wilks = 0.001, F = 269.1, effect df = 5, error df = 1, p = 0.046) but none of the Tukey's post-hocs had a significant result (p-values between 0.15 and 0.98). For further details see Supplementary Fig. S3.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Diagnosis of environmental health through biomarker-based risk assessment is a powerful new tool in ecosystem management. This is particularly evident for scientists working not only in the context of the EU Water Framework Directive, but also all over the world (Colin et al., 2016;Hook et al., 2014;Pretti and Cognetti-Varriale, 2001;Sherry, 2003). However, variability in biomarker levels may be seen as a potential shortcoming in their wide application throughout marine communities and ecosystems. Here, we present a comprehensive molecular assessment of wild populations to define general baseline patterns within broad taxonomic, seasonal and habitat contexts. As expected, there was a clear differentiation between phyla, likely due to inherent morphological, physiological and biochemical discrepancies, specific genetic traits and mode of life. Such traits need to be carefully evaluated in candidate species in order to establish appropriate bioindicators for environmental monitoring, minimizing problems associated with interpretation of biological responses (see Hagger et al., 2006 for a review).

Interestingly, sessile/sedentary species had greater levels of CSR proteins and lipid peroxidation when compared to mobile species. This further confirms the importance of mode of life in biomarker responses. As sessile species cannot escape unfavorable conditions, they are more prone to cellular damage due to environmental variation and extremes. As such, mechanisms of cellular protection are enhanced in these species, particularly Hsp70, to provide tolerance to environmental stressors. Selecting phyla with different life strategies in monitoring programs provides a more holistic approach to environmental risk assessment, as previously suggested by other authors, and is crucial to identify the full impact of contamination on marine ecosystems (Galloway et al., 2004). Besides taxonomic differences, intraspecific variation may be another source of confoundment in biomarker studies. Factors as sex, age, size, reproductive stage, health status, genotype and previous exposure are known to influence biomarker responses (Correia et al., 2003;Dalzochio and Gehlen, 2016;Madeira et al., 2012). In this study, intraspecific variation calculated as % CV was high for all biomarkers and species analyzed (mean %CV ranged from 35 to 94%) corroborating other studies (e.g. Correia et al., 2003). For instance, anti-oxidant enzymes measured in genetically identical cultured daphnids showed % CV ranging from 9 to as high as 32% whereas in field collected P. scaber the % CV was much higher (42-63%) (Jemec et al., 2010). Intraspecific variability is an important determinant of our aptitude to detect contaminant induced up-regulation of a biomarker. A biomarker that has low coefficient of variation is of great interest to biomonitoring as its change can truly signal environmental contamination, being considered a reliable measure (see White, 2011). Thus, % CV should be a criterion for biomarker validation and approval in environmental monitoring programs, easing the interpretation of results. Overall, GST, SOD and Hsp70 were the biomarkers that presented the lowest mean % CV suggesting their usefulness in pollution biomonitoring plans. If we look at species, the ones with the lowest variation (considering all biomarkers) were crustacean and fish species, ranging from 35.6 to 53.9% CV. One species of sea anemone was also within these values (52.9% CV, Anemonia sulcata). Thus, such species could be appointed as useful bioindicators.

Seasonal variation can be steep in temperate regions and is a significant factor shaping biomarker responses in different taxa, as also shown by other studies for instance in polyplacophores, mussels, clams, shrimps and fish (Banni et al., 2009;Feidantsis et al., 2013;Madeira et al., 2017;Madeira et al., 2016;Nahrgang et al., 2013;Padmini and Geetha, 2009;Shaw et al., 2004). In this study, fish and cnidarians showed clear seasonal clusters in the PCA, suggesting a stronger influence of seasonality in these taxa. Mollusks and especially crustaceans had less clear patterns highlighting the potential advantage of using these groups in pollution monitoring programs as they are less susceptible to seasonal environmental variation. However, such analyses should also be performed at the species level, as interspecies variability within each phyla is expected. Overall, lipid peroxidation and total ubiquitin levels were higher in spring while CSR proteins (anti-oxidant enzymes and Hsp70) were higher in summer. Such results could be explained by acclimatization processes and recent thermal history. For instance, the antioxidant capacity and protein quality control system could be low during spring because the environment is still warming and organisms are not yet fully acclimatized to heat, as the previous environmental conditions (winter) were mostly cold. The low cytoprotective capacity of the cells during spring could therefore explain the higher levels of oxidative damage (i.e. LPO). Alternatively, other studies have pointed out the role of LPO as a signaling mechanism in the cell, as stimulant of gene expression to enhance cytoprotection and cell survival (Ayala et al., 2014;Kagan, 2018;Niki, 2012), functioning as a preparative defense strategy that can induce adaptation of species in the long-term (Ayala et al., 2014). Still, during summer, organisms should be fully acclimatized, hence the higher levels of anti-oxidant enzymes and Hsp70 observed in fish and cnidarians. Despite some overlap between seasons in mollusks, a similar pattern was observed as all biomarkers were higher in summer except for LPO. Thus, it seems that the increase in CSR during summer may be enough to counteract oxidative damage to lipids. Biomarkers that are less responsive to season or other confounding factors in each taxa are very useful to be integrated in pollution monitoring programs, as the interpretation of results is easier, as noted by other authors (Hylland et al., 2009;Madeira et al., 2017;Vinagre et al., 2014). On the other hand, biomarkers and species that are more responsive to season could be pinpointed as bioindicators for climate change.

Habitat type can be an important determinant of tolerance to environmental variation, defining inter-population differences in physiology and cellular functioning (Madeira et al., 2012). Accordingly, the sea anemone A. equina and the mussel M. galloprovinciallis showed defined habitat clusters, suggesting either local adaptation due to shortterm selection or phenotypic plasticity elicited by the different environments. Both processes constitute important adaptive strategies in changing environments (Trussell and Etter, 2001). As both species have planktonic larval stages they have some dispersal capacity, possibly suggesting genetic flow between populations. In this case, the observed patterns could be due to phenotypic plasticity and acclimation and not local adaptation. However, adaptation of organisms to estuarine brackish water has been previously observed in species with high dispersal capacity, and has been suggested as a major factor shaping population differences (estuary vs coast) in several species, including mussels (Bulnheim, 1988). Cnidarians may also undergo local adaption to environmental stressors, even showing polymorphisms in proteins involved in cellular stress responses, as evidenced in Friedman et al. (2018). Interestingly, P. lineatus did not show clear habitat clusters and the statistical analysis showed a significant interaction between species and habitat in defining molecular patterns. Thus, this marine snail may have either low phenotypic plasticity or shows no local adaptation. In order to further confirm which process may be taking place (local adaptation vs phenotypic plasticity) data of population genetic structure over small spatial scales is needed. As estuaries are confined habitats subjected to high levels of natural and anthropogenic stressors (Pinto, 2011), we expected biomarker levels in A. equina and M. galloprovincialis to be higher in the estuary. However, the detected pattern was the opposite as specimens collected in the estuary had lower biomarker levels when compared to specimens collected in the coast. The same result was observed by Madeira et al. (2012) in a thermal stress laboratory experiment carried out using an intertidal crab collected in the same environments. The authors justify this by stating that the vertical zonation differed between the coast and estuary, potentially providing different ecological niches. This estuary is mostly sandy, with a few dispersed rocks close to the water while the coastal zone is mainly a wave-exposed rocky beach, where animals can occur at greater tidal heights and therefore be subjected to greater stress (desiccation, high temperature). Besides the environmental plateaus of each specific habitat, predictable environmental variation may be determinant in shaping physiological and biomarker responses (see Whiteley and McKenzie, 2016). For instance, even though the absolute temperature (of both air and water) is greater in the estuary, seasonal thermal variation in air temperature is lower (Δ12°C in the estuary vs Δ14°C in the coast). Additionally, animals located at the supra-littoral pools undergo larger seasonal variation when compared to those in the infralittoral (Δ6°C in the supra-littoral vs Δ4°C in the infra-littoral). Therefore, animals subjected to greater environmental variation may have an increased production of cytoprotective proteins (such as Hsp70, antioxidants, DNA repair proteins). Such assumption has already been tested in some intertidal species, confirming that intertidal height and microhabitat variation is a relevant factor shaping molecular responses (Clark et al., 2018;Tomanek and Helmuth, 2002). Therefore, we suggest that future studies address differences in biomarker responses between microhabitats, as they may be crucial for animals to maintain homeostasis (Nay et al., 2015), especially in species with low ability to induce cytoprotection in face of environmental change. In these cases, behavioral changes may play a role in survival under fluctuating environments and this should be adequately assessed. Future research should also focus on evaluating the differences between biomarker responses in communities from key habitats or biomes, for instance rocky reefs, biogenic (coral) reefs, mangroves, sandy sea beds and seagrass beds. Tropical areas will become a fruitful area of research under this topic as they present non-seasonal environments which would render less variability in biomarker responses, and monitoring programs are urgently needed (Madeira, 2018;Madeira et al., 2018). In order to facilitate such comparisons, we suggest the use of a set of the most appropriate biomarkers and combine them in integrated biomarker indices of stress (Madeira et al., 2018;Marigómez et al., 2013).

To conclude, environmental stressors are known to impact the marine environment at lower levels of biological organization (molecular, cellular) before scaling up into effects at higher organization levels (organismal, community, ecosystem). As such, biomarkers are early warning indicators, useful to diagnose and track ecosystem health issues at a sub-lethal phase before ecosystem deterioration is irremediable (Sherry, 2003). This study highlights differences in biomarker levels across marine taxa, seasons and habitat types, contributing to the understanding of baseline variability levels. In order to define the most appropriate indicator species and biomarkers to apply, it is necessary to consider the final objectives of the biomonitoring program as well as the locations where it will be implemented: i) evaluate the short term and/or long term effects of specific events (e.g. chemical pollution, organic discharges, climate related extreme events such as heat waves, etc.); the effect of confounding factors in the responses and the intraspecific variation of each biomarker. Herein we suggest that for longterm pollution monitoring, Carcinus maenas may be used as an indicator species (low intraspecific variability in responses), both in estuaries and coastal areas and a good candidate marker in this species is Hsp70 (low coefficient of variation), whereas for long-term climate change monitoring, intertidal habitats could very well be a natural laboratory for such studies (high inducibility of biomarker responses), using sessile/ sedentary cnidarian, gastropod and chiton species which were highly responsive to season (e.g. A. equina, A. punctata and P. depressa in the coast and M. galloprovincialis and C. angulata in the estuary). In general, anti-oxidant enzymes such as CAT and SOD changed with climaterelated variation, being relevant marker candidates in climate change monitoring. Finally, tissue assessments should also be carried out, as depending on tissue, biomarker responses may vary due to intrinsic metabolic activity and consequent differences in O 2 demand and ROS flux (Madeira et al., 2014b). In this study, we standardized tissue as much as possible by collecting muscle in most species. However, small invertebrates may present challenges when it comes to collecting a specific organ, so the whole body may need to be analyzed. For the purpose of this study, muscle and whole body were comparable in terms of biomarker levels. Nevertheless, multiorgan approaches should be carried out once a bioindicator species is chosen, in order to select suitable target organs for monitoring. The information obtained here can be used to define sampling strategies and overcome interpretation issues (Hylland et al., 2009). As Hagger et al. (2006) also pointed out, a greater understanding of the variations in biomarker responses is needed in order to successfully integrate biomarkers in environmental risk assessment within the EU Water Framework Directive and similar environmental monitoring programs around the world.
